title: Lyme Disease Is Spreading Fast. Why Isn’t There a Vaccine?
abstract: The only vaccine was taken off the market more than 15 years ago. As reports of the disease skyrocket, researchers are working on a new one.

title: Should You Choose a Female Doctor?
abstract: Studies show that female doctors tend to listen more, and their patients — both male and female — tend to fare better.

title: Why Sitting May Be Bad for Your Brain
abstract: Taking a walk every 30 minutes can restore blood flow to the brain when you’re sitting for hours.

title: They Thought Hemophilia Was a ‘Lifelong Thing.’ They May Be Wrong.
abstract: Experimental gene therapies have yielded promising results in early trials. But the drugs have left some patients wary, worried that success will not last.

title: Clues to Your Health Are Hidden at 6.6 Million Spots in Your DNA
abstract: With a sophisticated new algorithm, scientists have found a way to forecast an individual’s risks for five deadly diseases.

title: U.S. Ambassador Denies Threatening Ecuador Over Breast-Feeding Resolution
abstract: Ambassador Todd C. Chapman said that allegations he pressured the country by threatening trade sanctions and withdrawal of military aid were “patently false.”

title: With Short, Intense Sessions, Some Patients Finish Therapy in Just Weeks
abstract: The new psychological approach targets anxiety, PTSD and other mental disorders. Fewer people drop out with short-term treatment, and relief is quicker.

title: Inducing Labor at 39 Weeks May Offer Benefits
abstract: First-time mothers who had labor induced at 39 weeks were less likely to need C-sections.

title: The Large Hidden Costs of Medicare’s Prescription Drug Program
abstract: Premiums have risen very little in the years since Medicare Part D was introduced. But the same cannot be said of the burden on taxpayers.

title: Report Finds Traces of a Controversial Herbicide in Cheerios and Quaker Oats
abstract: The herbicide glyphosate is the world’s most popular weedkiller. There is widespread disagreement among lawyers, researchers and regulators over any potential links to cancer.

title: Any Weight Loss Can Be Healthful, but More Can Be Much Better
abstract: Overweight people who lost 5 to 10 percent of their weight lowered their risk for metabolic syndrome by 22 percent. Those who lost 20 percent cut their risk by over 50 percent.

title: For Online Daters, Women Peak at 18 While Men Peak at 50, Study Finds. Oy.
abstract: The study, which looked at nearly 200,000 users, also showed that a man’s desirability increased with greater education. For women, it was another story.

title: Bleak New Estimates in Drug Epidemic: A Record 72,000 Overdose Deaths in 2017
abstract: Fentanyl is a big culprit, but there are also encouraging signs from states that have prioritized public health campaigns and addiction treatment.

title: Singing With My Grandbaby
abstract: Researchers say that singing is among the most meaningful activities we share with children.

title: Black Boys Feel Less Safe in White Neighborhoods, Study Shows
abstract: African-American boys “will expect increased scrutiny, surveillance and even direct targeting as they traverse whiter spaces,” researchers at Ohio State University found.

title: The ‘Zombie Gene’ That May Protect Elephants From Cancer
abstract: With such enormous bodies, elephants should be particularly prone to tumors. But an ancient gene in their DNA, somehow resurrected, seems to shield the animals.

title: My Patient’s Sisters
abstract: It was vividly clear, in every touch and gaze, that a patient’s family had made the right decision.

title: An Underappreciated Key to College Success: Sleep
abstract: Many college-bound students start out with dreadful sleep habits that are likely to get worse once the rigorous demands of courses and competing social and athletic activities kick in.

title: How to Minimize Repetitive Stress Injuries From Carrying a Baby
abstract: The early months as a baby grows can be hard on a parent’s muscles, because none of that “weight lifting” is guided by the strengthening — or the safety — of the parent.

title: A Congressman, a Financial Deal and an Intricate Web of Conflicts
abstract: The allegations of insider trading against Representative Christopher Collins have revived calls for stricter rules about financial investments or corporate board seats held by members of Congress.

title: Maria Konnikova Shows Her Cards
abstract: The well-regarded science writer took up poker while researching a book. Now she’s on the professional circuit.

title: As Catholic Hospitals Expand, So Do Limits on Some Procedures
abstract: Many religious health care institutions do not make it clear up front what procedures they won’t perform, a New York Times analysis shows.

title: Paula Schneider on Running American Apparel and Fighting Cancer
abstract: A breast cancer survivor who ran one of the most notorious brands in fashion is now C.E.O. of Susan G. Komen, working to raise money for a cure.

title: Can You Screen for Early Pancreatic Cancer?
abstract: Pancreatic cancer is best treated at the earliest stages, but it is hard to detect.

title: Going Solo: An Author Chooses — and Celebrates — Life Without a Partner or Kids
abstract: Glynnis MacNicol’s smart, pithy memoir, “No One Tells You This,” celebrates women who buck cultural norms.

title: Getting Kids to Eat More Vegetables
abstract: Plates illustrated with pictures of vegetables spurred children to eat more of them.

title: Court Orders E.P.A. to Ban Chlorpyrifos, Pesticide Tied to Children’s Health Problems
abstract: The ruling by a federal appeals court was a major setback for the pesticide industry, which had successfully lobbied the Trump administration to reject a ban.

title: Food Quality Trumps Variety, Experts Say
abstract: People whose diets contained the greatest variety of foods tended to eat many nutritious foods, but also many junk foods.

title: Boxers or Briefs? It May Depend on Your Fertility Goals
abstract: Sperm count and concentration were higher in men who wore boxers versus tighter underwear styles.

title: My Voice Got Deeper. Suddenly, People Listened.
abstract: My feminist mother taught me to speak up. Now, as a trans man, I am trying to make space for women to be heard.

title: Companies Respond to an Urgent Health Care Need: Transportation
abstract: As people grow older and prefer to manage their health care at home, more need transportation to doctors and outpatient services. Business is surging.

title: Psychologists’ Group Maintains Ban on Work at Military Detention Facilities
abstract: Members of the American Psychological Association voted against allowing psychologists to resume work at certain detention centers like the one in Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.
